description: The Jubilee Hall, which houses the Jubilee Market, was built in 1904 in the heart of Covent Garden and gained Grade 2 listed status in 1980. The market was officially re opened after renovation by Queen Elizabeth II in 1987.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: By 1654 a small open-air fruit-and-vegetable market had developed on the south side of the fashionable Covent Garden square in London. Gradually, both the market and the surrounding area fell into disrepute, as taverns, theatres, coffee-houses and brothels opened up. An Act of Parliament was drawn up to control the area, and Charles Fowler's neo-classical building was erected in 1830 to cover and help organise the market. The market grew and further buildings were added: the Floral Hall, Charter Market, and in 1904 the Jubilee Market running the length of Tavistock Street, named after the then Duke of Bedford, Marquess of Tavistock. We see the building as it stands today, a solid rectangular structure standing next to the London Transport Museum. After a major renovation of the Jubilee Market itself, beginning in 1985 and lasting 2 years, it was re opened by Queen Elizabeth II on 5th August 1987, as commemorated by a stone  plaque in the façade of the market.

factsheet.heading: Trading as a market today
paragraphs: The Jubilee Market today has a wide variety of eclectic weekend Arts and Crafts stalls, offering everything from UK made or designed jewellery, candles, perfumes and clothing, or on a Monday it hosts a vibrant antiques market followed on Tuesdays to Fridays by a General Market. With a wide range of food outlets, you can enjoy your trip to Jubilee Market with choices from traditional English breakfasts served all day at Peter's Snack Bar, German hot dogs, Crepes and ice creams, smoothies, and authentic Italian food from Prima Sapori, a family run restaurant within the market walls. Jubilee Market also has a bureau de change and a Box Office ticketing agency within its walls. It is instantly recognizable with its exciting atmosphere, flags, brass signage and commemorative bunting and lively family friendly atmosphere.

factsheet.heading: Significant Plaques - In detail
paragraphs: Jubilee Market traders laid a large stone plaque to commemorate the creation of the covered street market, funded by the traders themselves, and to pay tribute to  Ray Green, first Chairman and Trustee of the Jubilee Market Traders Committee. Its dedication and strength of purpose were instrumental in securing the future of the market.
The stone plaque commemorating Elizabeth II visit to re-open the market on 5th August 1987 is on the façade of the building.
A plaque on the Piazza facing promenade reads "Speyhawk Land & Estates Ltd, 1987. Contractors: Tellings Ltd. Architects: C.G.H.P. Architects".
There is also a plaque dedicated to the memory of the 100,000 costermongers' donkeys that worked in and around the market. This was supplied by the South East Working Donkey Group.

A bronze by Glynis Jones Owen on Southampton St honours all those men and women who bought and sold fresh produce here, which was then distributed throughout England. The bronze relief "Fruit Porter Bronze", was unveiled October 2006 by the Mayor of Westminster. Commissioned by Worshipful Company of Fruiterers, with contributions from many of the market traders and by Westminster City Council & Covent Garden Area Trust

On the rear of the Jubilee Market building on Tavistock Street there is the family crest of the Russell family, the Dukes of Bedford, with their family motto, 'que sera, sera', 'Whatever will be, will be'. The famous Academy Award winning song was sung by Doris Day in the Hitchcock film The Man who Knew Too Much (1956).
